Is then the final page before me spread,</br>Nor further outlet left to mind or heart?</br>Presumptuous Book!  too forward to be read—</br>How can I give thee licence to depart?</br>One tribute more; — unbidden feelings start</br>Forth from their coverts — slighted objects rise—</br>My Spirit is the scene of such wild art</br>As on Parnassus rules, when lightning flies,</br>Visibly leading on the thunder's harmonies.

All that I saw returns upon my view,</br>All that I heard comes back upon my ear,</br>All that I felt this moment doth renew;</br>And where the foot with no unmanly fear</br>Recoil'd — and wings alone could travel — there</br>I move at ease; and meet contending themes</br>That press upon me, crossing the career</br>Of recollections vivid as the dreams</br>Of midnight, — cities — plains — forests — and mighty streams!

Where mortal never breathed I dare to sit</br>Among the interior Alps, gigantic crew,</br>Who triumphed o'er diluvian power! — and yet</br>What are they but a wreck and residue,</br>Whose only business is to perish? — true</br>To which sad course, these wrinkled Sons of Time</br>Labour their proper greatness to subdue;</br>Speaking of death alone, beneath a clime</br>Where life and rapture flow in plenitude sublime.

Fancy hath flung for me an airy bridge</br>Across the long deep Valley, furious Rhone!</br>Arch that here rests upon the granite ridge</br>Of Monte Rosa — there, on frailer stone</br>Of secondary birth — the Jung-frau's cone;</br>And, from that arch down-looking on the Vale</br>The aspect I behold of every zone;</br>A sea of foliage tossing with the gale,</br>Blithe Autumn's purple crown, and Winter's icy mail!

Far as ST. MAURICE, from yon eastern FORKS,</br>Down the main avenue my sight can range:</br>And all its branchy vales, and all that lurks</br>Within them, church, and town, and hut, and grange,</br>For my enjoyment meet in vision strange;</br>Snows — torrents; — to the region's utmost bound,</br>Life, Death, in amicable interchange—</br>But list!  the avalanche — heart-striking sound!</br>Tumult by prompt repose and awful silence crown'd!

Is not the Chamois suited to his place?</br>The Eagle worthy of her ancestry?</br>—Let Empires fall; but ne'er shall Ye disgrace</br>Your noble birthright, Ye that occupy</br>Your Council-seats beneath the open sky,</br>On Sarnen's Mount, there judge of fit and right,</br>In simple democratic majesty;</br>Soft breezes fanning your rough brows — the might</br>And purity of nature spread before your sight!

From this appropriate Court, renown'd LUCERNE</br>Leads me to pace her honoured Bridge — that cheers</br>The Patriot's heart with Pictures rude and stern,</br>An uncouth Chronicle of glorious years.</br>Like portraiture, from loftier source, endears</br>That work of kindred frame, which spans the Lake</br>Just at the point of issue, where it fears</br>The form and motion of a Stream to take;</br>Where it begins to stir, Yet voiceless as a Snake.

Volumes of sound, from the Cathedral roll'd,</br>This long-roofed Vista penetrate — but see,</br>One after one, its Tablets, that unfold</br>The whole design of Scripture history;</br>From the first tasting of the fatal Tree,</br>Till the bright Star appeared in eastern skies,</br>Announcing, ONE was born Mankind to free;</br>His acts, his wrongs, his final sacrifice;</br>Lessons for every heart, a Bible for all eyes.

Our pride misleads, our timid likings kill.</br>—Long may these homely Works devised of old,</br>These simple Efforts of Helvetian skill,</br>Aid, with congenial influence, to uphold</br>The State, — the Country's destiny to mould;</br>Turning, for them who pass, the common dust</br>Of servile opportunity to gold;</br>Filling the soul with sentiments august—</br>The beautiful, the brave, the holy, and the just!

And those surrounding Mountains — but no more;</br>Time creepeth softly as the liquid flood;</br>Life slips from underneath us, like the floor</br>Of that wide rainbow-arch whereon we stood,</br>Earth stretched below, Heaven in our neighbourhood.</br>Go forth, my little Book!  pursue thy way;</br>Go forth, and please the gentle and the good;</br>Nor be a whisper stifled, if it say</br>That treasures, yet untouched, may grace some future Lay.</br>
